CATALYSIS A: GENERAL ELSEVIER Applied Catalysis A: General 150 (1997) 63-76 The effect of alkali metal salts on ZnO/a-A12 O 3 and MnO2 catalysts for the oxidative coupling of methane Sang Chai Kim a,*, Su Jin Kim b, Eui Yeon Yu c a Department of Environmental Engineering and Education, Mokpo National University, Muan 534-729, South Korea b Chemical Engineering Division, Korea Research Institute of Chemical Technology, P.O. Box 107, Yusung, Taejon 305-606, South Korea c Department of Chemical Engineering, Chonnam National University, Kwangju 500-757, South Korea Received 22 February 1996; revised 19 June 1996; accepted 29 July 1996 Abstract A series of alkali metal halides/ZnO(60 wt.-%)/a-Al203 and NaC1/MnO2 were tested for the oxidative coupling of methane to ethylene and ethane. Sodium halides such as NaF, NaCl, NaBr and NaJ were used as alkali metal halides. Recorded activities were associated with the apparent molal enthalpy of formation of sodium halides. The activity order was NaBr > NaC1 > NaI > NaF. NaC1 and NaBr played a role as promoters. NaF and Na! played a role as inhibitors. A kinetic study showed the reaction over NaCI(30 wt.-%)/ZnO(60 wt.-%)/a-A1203 was of the dual site Langmuir-Hinshelwood type. The obtained activation energy for the methyl radical formation was ca. 39 kcal/mole. The active oxygen species responsible for methyl radical formation seems to be a diatomic oxygen such as 02- or 02 adsorbed on the surface of the catalyst. Keywords: Oxidative coupling of methane; Sodium halides; Dual site Langmuir-Hinshelwood; Methyl radical; Active oxygen species I. Introduction The production of natural gas is increasing year by year and its reserves are located all over the world. Methane is the most abundant gas among the various gases in natural gas, and is still being considered as an alternative source for petrochemicals. * Tel.: ( + 82-636) 4502781; fax: ( + 82-636) 4534843. 0926-860X/97/$17.00 Copyright 1997 Elsevier Science B.V. Kim et al. / Applied Catalysis A: General 150 (1997) 63-76 Oxidative coupling of methane is a way for the direct conversion of methane to ethylene and ethane which are more valuable products than methane. Since the pioneering work of Keller and Bhasin [1], the oxidative coupling of methane has attracted much attention. Activities of many metal oxides catalysts have been summarized in recent reviews [2-7]. A practical goal in the oxidative coupling of methane is to produce high yields of ethylene because ethylene is more valuable than ethane. However, ethane is the primary product of the reaction and ethylene which may be produced by the dehydrogenation of ethane is the secondary product. Several groups have reported that the dehydrogenation reaction is enhanced by chlorine, either added into the catalyst or introduced into the reactant stream as HC1 or as an organic chloride [8-11]. Also, it is well known that methyl radicals which are generated by the interaction of methane with surface oxygen species such as O- and O2, couple in the gas phase to produce ethylene and ethane, but at present there is no consensus as to the likely mechanism governing the surface chemical reactions. In this work, the effect of alkali metal salts (NaI, NaBr, NaC1, NaF, NaNO3, LizCO3 and KNO3) on ZnO/ce-Al203 and MnO2 catalysts was investigated; especially the role of halogens in sodium halides has been exam- ined. Kinetic studies were carried out to elucidate the active oxygen species of the NaC1/ZnO/a-A1203 catalyst system. 2. Experimental 2.1. Catalyst preparation Commercial Zn(NO3)2.6H20 was dissolved in deionized water, and then added into an NH4OH aqueous solution of a pH value between 9 and 10 to precipitate Zn(OH)2. The precipitation was washed thoroughly and filtered several times by deionized water until the solution reached pH 7. It was dried in an oven at 125 for 24 h. Zn(OH)2 and ce-A1203 were added into a solution where an alkali metal salt (NaI, NaBr, NaCI, NaF, NaNO3, Li2CO3 or KNO3) was dissolved or mixed in deionized water. The resulting slurry was heated to 80 while stirring to evaporate excess water until a thick paste formed. The thick paste was dried in an oven at 125 for 14 h and calcined in air at 800 for 6 h. The resultant was crushed and powdered to prepare final catalysts. NaCI and MnO2 were mixed together in deionized water. The same proce- dure was repeated to prepare final catalysts. 2.2. Apparatus and method A conventional fixed bed flow reactor in the shape of a U was used as the experimental apparatus [12]. The dimensions of the reactor are 1.1 cm i.d. and S.C. Kim et al. / Applied Catalysis A: General 150 (1997) 63-76 65 38 cm long at the inlet section and 0.5 cm i.d. and 29 cm long at the outlet section. The catalyst (0.5 g) was mechanically mixed with sea sand (3 g) as a diluent before being packed into the reactor to obtain a uniform dispersion of the catalyst for better yield of hydrocarbon and more uniform temperature distribu- tion. The catalyst was held in place by Raschig ring and a small plug of quartz wool. The reactor was heated with an electric tubular furnace to a desired temperature. The temperature was controlled within an accuracy of ___ 1.0 using a PID temperature controller. In most experiments, flow rates of methane and oxygen were 4 cc/min and 2 cc/min, respectively. The CH4/O2 molar ratio of 2 is the stoichiometric ratio for conversion of CH4 and 02 to C2H4 and H20. The total flow rate was maintained at 50 cc/min, and at 100 cc/min in kinetic experiment by adding the balance gas, N2. The gaseous reactants were mixed in a mixing chamber which was packed with Rasching rings, and then purified by passing them through a purifier that contained blue silica and molecular sieve. Effluent gases were analyzed with an on-line gas chromatography (model 7AG, Shimadzu Co.) system, employed with the porapak Q column (3 mm, 3 m long, 60/80 mesh) and the molecular sieve 5A column (3 mm, 3 m long, 60/80 mesh). The catalysts were characterized with X-ray powder diffraction (XRD, Geigerflex, Rigaku), energy dispersive X-ray analysis (EDXA, AN10000, Link) and a differential thermal analysis (TG-DTA, STA1640, Stanton Redcroft). BET surface areas were measured by nitrogen physisorption at -196 with a Micromeritics ASAP2000 system. The activity of the catalyst was determined using three terms which are defined as follows: Conversion (%) = [(moles of converted methane)/(moles of methane input)] 100 Selectivity (%) = [(moles of converted methane into the desired component products)/(moles of converted methane)] 100 Yield (%) = [(moles of converted methane into the desired products)/(moles of methane input)] 100 3. Results and discussion 3.1. Effect of alkali metal salts Our preceding paper [12] reported that a-Al203 which had few acid sites in the Zn-oxide catalyst system was an excellent support and 60 wt.-% was the optimum loading concentration in the oxidative coupling of methane. Chlorine gave a great effect on the formation of C2H4 [8-11]. Since chlorine is known to affect the dehydrogenation of C2H6 in the gas phase, it has been suspected that homogeneous reactions may be responsible for the large formation ratios of 66 S.C. The fresh catalysts and the used catalysts which underwent the reaction for 10 h were analyzed with EDXA. The results of EDXA analysis are shown in Fig. 3. Fig. 3 shows that each component of sodium halides exists in the fresh catalysts, but has been diminished or disappeared in the used catalysts. Therefore, it seems that the Br radical of NaBr and C1 radical of NaC1 catalyze the formation of CzH4 from CH4 but I radical of NaI and F radical of NaF does not catalyze that of CzH4 from CH4. The actual activity order was discrepant from the estimated activity order. This discrepancy might be attributed to the dissociation energy of sodium halides, that is, NaI easily dissociates to Na and I at much lower temperatures than the reaction temperature (750). Subsequently, I radicals can be easily lost. But NaF hardly dissociates to Na and F at the same temperature. Therefore, F radicals can hardly be formed. NaF cannot be detected with EDXA because elements with atomic weights lower than Ne could not be detected with EDXA. The apparent activation energy obtained from the slope of the Arrhenius plot was ca. 39 kcal/mole. The active oxygen species responsible for the activation of CH4 have been reported as O- [19-22], 02 [18,23,24], 022- [18,23,25] and 02- [26]. As the results from this kinetic work indicate that active oxygen species are dioxygen, 02 or 022- which adsorb on the surface of NaC1 (30 wt.-%)/ZnO (60 wt.-%)/a-AlzO3 catalyst, they may be considered as the active oxygen species. However, 02- could be considered as a dimer of O- because transition of 02- to 20- was exothermic; ca. 34 kcal/mol [4]. Therefore, considering many reports that O- take part in the activation of CH4, 022- can be regarded as the stable form of O- even though there are differences among catalyst systems, subsequently, it may have to be considered that the O- species take part in the activation of CH4. These results indicate that addition of alkali halides is responsible for the creation of active oxygen species, that is, addition of NaI or NaF into ZnO (60 wt.-%)/a-A1203 inhibits the formation of active oxygen species, while addition of NaC1 or NaBr into ZnO (60 wt.-%)/a-AlzO3 promotes the formation of active oxygen species. Conclusions (1) When four kinds of sodium halides were added into ZnO (60 wt.-%)/o~- AI203, the catalytic activity order was shown to be NaBr > NaC1 > NaI > NaF at 750. The deactivation of NaC1/Mn203 catalyst was mainly due to the loss of NaCI. (2) The reaction over NaC1 (30 wt.-%)/ZnO (60 wt.-%)/a-A1203 was a dual site of the Langmuir-Hinshelwood type. A series of alkali metal halides/ZnO(60 wt.-%)/α-Al2O3 and NaCl MnO2 were tested for the oxidative coupling of methane to ethylene and ethane. Sodium halides such as NaF, NaCl, NaBr and NaI were used as alkali metal halides. Recorded activities were associated with the apparent molal enthalpy of formation of sodium halides. The activity order was NaBr > NaCl > NaI > NaF. NaCl and NaBr played a role as promoters. NaF and NaI played a role as inhibitors. A kinetic study showed the reaction over NaCl(30 wt.-%)/ZnO(60 wt.-%)/α-Al2O3 was of the dual site Langmuir-Hinshelwood type. The obtained activation energy for the methyl radical formation was ca. 39 kcal/mole. The active oxygen species responsible for methyl radical formation seems to be a diatomic oxygen such as O2 2− or O2 − adsorbed on the surface of the catalyst.
